A lot of geometric and 45-degree angles this Friday with work from Portland, New York, and Monterrey.

Boreal by Hovercraft Studio

Opened in 1964 in Truckee, CA, atop of Donner Summit, Boreal is a ski and snowboard resort with thriving activity. And a bad-ass logo. Designed by Portland, OR-based Hovercraft Studio, the logo is an abstract “B” rotated 45 degrees right to leave a mountain shape pointing up and topped with a simple depiction of snow. It’s simple, it’s smart, it has snowboarder appeal and it’s well done. The visuals and advertising campaign have a fun, Roy Lichtenstein-dot approach in a minty color palette that add to the festive feel of Boreal. See full project.

Design by Hand by OCD

Presented by the Cooper-Hewitt from fall 2013 through spring 2017, Design by Hand is a series that “focuses on the craftsmanship, innovations, and merits of contemporary global designers.” Designed by New York, NY-based OCD | The Original Champions of Design, the logo and identity resisted the urge to be, you know, designed by hand and be all scribbly. Instead, a perfectly crafted, abstract hand figure that conveys both that everything is A-ok and that whatever it is holding has been hand-picked. Drawing hands as logos is amazingly difficult — just ask United Way, then and now — and this works so great in its geometric approach. There is also a great mid-twentieth-century aesthetic going on with the color palette, chunky typography and repetition of form. See full project.

Xoclad by Anagrama

With pre-Hispanic words the “X” is pronounced as “SH” so the name for this new pastry and confectionery shop in the Mayan Riviera in Mexico, Xoclad, is pronounced like chocolate. A clever way to bring in an “X” into the mix, because “X”s are awesome. Designed by Anagrama, the simple wordmark is accompanied by a crazy-looking pattern that is representative of many of the decorations you would find in ruins across the region. The pattern looks best when used in small details like the piece of tape or the cloth for the spreads. I also liked the stacked boxes of typography in the business cards, giving it a contemporary look reminiscent of the KarlssonWilker house style. The pink and mint color palette adds to the overall quirky vibe. See full project.
